 I think priests are pretty safe from civil liability. No church makes a contract guaranteeing they will marry their members no matter what, and they are not obligated to marry non-members in any case -- you couldn't force a Catholic church to accommodate a Muslim wedding, for example. And no, I don't think you could launch a civil case against a priest who refused to sanctify a racially "unacceptable" marriage, either. Churches are exempt from laws pertaining to racial equality -- only government is bound by them.
 
 So yes, I suppose you could get a civil suit against a town clerk or justice of the peace who refused a civil ceremony in a state that allowed them, and if the clerk or JP happened also to be a clergyman, then he'd still be liable -- but not in his capacity as a cleric, but a civil official. But you couldn't force a priest to hold a marriage ceremony in his own church against his wishes or beliefs, no matter how repugnant they might be.
 
 Thank the first amendment for that.
